title: Docker Fundamentals
description: Test your knowledge of Docker basics, containers, and images.

questions.question: What is Docker?
questions.explanation: Docker is an open-source platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers.

questions.question: How are Docker containers different from virtual machines?
options: Containers share the host OS kernel, VMs have their own OS
questions.correctAnswer: Containers share the host OS kernel, VMs have their own OS
questions.explanation: Containers share the host system's kernel, making them lightweight compared to VMs which include a full operating system.

questions.question: What is a Docker image?
questions.explanation: A Docker image is a lightweight, standalone, executable package that includes everything needed to run an application.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Dockerfile?
options: To define how to build a Docker image
questions.correctAnswer: To define how to build a Docker image
questions.explanation: A Dockerfile is a text file with instructions for building a Docker image.

questions.question: Which command runs a container from an image?
questions.explanation: docker run creates and starts a container from a specified image.

questions.question: What does 'docker ps' show?
questions.explanation: docker ps lists all running containers. Use docker ps -a to see all containers.

questions.question: Which command builds a Docker image from a Dockerfile?
questions.explanation: docker build builds an image from a Dockerfile in the current directory.

questions.question: How do you map a container port to a host port?
questions.explanation: The -p flag maps container ports to host ports in the format host_port:container_port.

title: Advanced Docker Concepts
description: Explore Docker Compose, volumes, networking, and orchestration.

questions.question: What is Docker Compose used for?
questions.explanation: Docker Compose allows you to define and run multi-container Docker applications using a YAML file.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Docker volumes?
options: To persist data beyond container lifecycle
questions.explanation: Docker volumes provide persistent storage, allowing data to persist beyond container lifecycle and be shared between containers.

questions.question: What is the default Docker network driver?
questions.explanation: The bridge network driver is the default and creates an internal network for containers to communicate.

questions.question: What does the FROM instruction do in a Dockerfile?
options: Specifies the base image to build upon
questions.correctAnswer: Specifies the base image to build upon
questions.explanation: FROM specifies the base image that subsequent instructions will build upon.

questions.question: What is the benefit of multi-stage Docker builds?
questions.explanation: Multi-stage builds allow you to use different base images for building and running, resulting in smaller, more secure final images.

questions.question: What is Docker Hub?
options: A public registry for Docker images
questions.correctAnswer: A public registry for Docker images
questions.explanation: Docker Hub is a cloud-based registry service for sharing and managing Docker images.

questions.question: What is Docker Swarm?
options: Docker's native clustering and orchestration solution
questions.correctAnswer: Docker's native clustering and orchestration solution
questions.explanation: Docker Swarm is Docker's native tool for clustering and orchestrating Docker containers across multiple hosts.

questions.question: What is a Docker security best practice?
options: Run only one process per container
questions.correctAnswer: Run only one process per container
questions.explanation: Running only one process per container follows the single responsibility principle and improves security and maintainability.
